title: CLAUDE.md
text: file provides guidance Claude Code (claude.ai/code) working code repository.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: R package maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) series system parameters masked component failure data. package implements likelihood models systems : - Component lifetimes may masked (right-censored) - Component cause failure masked via candidate sets (subsets components plausibly contain failed component) - Masking conditions C1, C2, C3 satisfied

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # Install dependencies (including GitHub remotes) Rscript -e "devtools::install_deps(dependencies = TRUE)"  # Load package for interactive development Rscript -e "devtools::load_all()"  # Generate documentation from roxygen2 comments Rscript -e "devtools::document()"  # Run all tests Rscript -e "devtools::test()"  # Run a specific test file Rscript -e "devtools::test(filter = 'exp_series_md')"  # Run tests with coverage Rscript -e "covr::package_coverage()"  # Run R CMD check Rscript -e "devtools::check()"  # Build pkgdown site Rscript -e "pkgdown::build_site()"

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Three likelihood model classes, using S3 generic dispatch: model implements S3 methods: loglik(), score(), hess_loglik(), assumptions(), rdata() S3 class hierarchy (multiple inheritance dispatch): Implementation note: exponential model computes score Hessian analytically. Weibull models compute score analytically use numDeriv::jacobian score Hessian. Usage pattern:
code: c("exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3", "series_md", "likelihood_model") c("wei_series_md_c1_c2_c3", "series_md", "likelihood_model") c("wei_series_homogeneous_md_c1_c2_c3", "series_md", "likelihood_model") model <- exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3() ll_fn <- loglik(model)     # Returns function(df, par, ...) s_fn <- score(model)       # Returns function(df, par, ...) H_fn <- hess_loglik(model) # Returns function(df, par, ...) gen_fn <- rdata(model)     # Returns function(theta, n, tau, p, ...)  # Evaluate ll_value <- ll_fn(df, par = c(0.5, 0.3, 0.2))  # Generate simulated masked data df <- gen_fn(theta = c(0.5, 0.3, 0.2), n = 100, tau = 10, p = 0.5)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: C1: Failed component candidate set probability 1 C2: Uniform probability candidate sets conditioned component cause C3: Masking probabilities independent system parameters

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Generate component lifetimes (t1, t2, ...) Apply md_series_lifetime_right_censoring() → adds t, delta Apply md_bernoulli_cand_c1_c2_c3() → adds q1, q2, ... Apply md_cand_sampler() → adds x1, x2, ... Fit model using t x1, x2, ... columns

title: CLAUDE.md
text: t1, t2, ..., tm: Component lifetimes (latent) t: System lifetime (observed) delta: Right-censoring indicator (TRUE = exact, FALSE = censored) q1, q2, ..., qm: Candidate set probabilities (latent) x1, x2, ..., xm: Boolean candidate set indicators (observed)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Standalone R-style distribution functions (part likelihood models): dexp_series, pexp_series, qexp_series, rexp_series, hazard_exp_series, surv.exp_series

title: CLAUDE.md
text: md.tools: md_decode_matrix(), md_encode_matrix(), md_mark_latent() algebraic.mle: MLE objects $theta.hat, $sigma, $info algebraic.dist: Distribution utilities likelihood.model: Generics loglik, score, hess_loglik, assumptions, fim, observed_info, rdata generics: fit generic Note: fim observed_info re-exported likelihood.model use default implementations (Monte Carlo FIM, negated Hessian observed info). model-specific overrides needed.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Exponential series: System lifetime T = min(T₁,…,Tₘ) ~ Exp(λ = Σλⱼ) Homogeneous Weibull: shapes equal k, system lifetime ~ Weibull(k, βₛ) βₛ = (Σβⱼ⁻ᵏ)⁻¹/ᵏ. Use wei_series_system_scale(k, scales) compute. Log-likelihood (C1, C2, C3):
code: ℓ(θ) = -Σᵢ [survival term] + Σᵢ:δᵢ=1 log(Σⱼ∈Cᵢ hⱼ(tᵢ))

title: CLAUDE.md
text: cum_haz(haz): Creates cumulative hazard hazard function qcomp(p, haz, surv, theta, t_lower, t_upper): Quantile via root-finding rcomp(n, haz, surv, theta): Random generation via inverse transform

text: Tests use testthat edition 3. Test files mirror source files:

text: Functions: snake_case (e.g., md_series_lifetime_right_censoring) Distributions: R conventions (d*, p*, q*, r*) S3 registration: #' @method generic class + #' @export Model constructors accept column name overrides: lifetime, indicator, candset params

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Unified Censoring API: models accept indicator parameter (default: "delta") specifying column right-censoring status. backwards compatibility, column absent, censoring inferred empty candidate sets (FALSE).

title: Censoring Types in Series System Masked Data
text: monitoring series system, observation mechanism determines learn system failure time Ti=min(Ti1,…,Tim)T_i = \min(T_{i1}, \ldots, T_{im}). package supports four observation types, arising different monitoring design. Exact (ωi=exact\omega_i = \text{exact}). system failure time tit_i observed directly. occurs continuous monitoring system fails study period. log-likelihood contribution ℓiexact(θ)=logS(ti;θ)+loghc(ti;θ), \ell_i^{\text{exact}}(\theta) = \log S(t_i; \theta) + \log h_c(t_i; \theta),  S(t)S(t) system survival function hc(t)=∑j∈cihj(t)h_c(t) = \sum_{j \c_i} h_j(t) candidate-set hazard. Right-censored (ωi=right\omega_i = \text{right}). system known survived past time tit_i, actual failure time unknown. arises study ends system fails. contribution ℓiright(θ)=logS(ti;θ). \ell_i^{\text{right}}(\theta) = \log S(t_i; \theta).  Note right-censored observations carry candidate set information. Left-censored (ωi=left\omega_i = \text{left}). system known failed inspection time τi\tau_i, know . occurs single-inspection design: system found failed inspection, failure time left-censored τi\tau_i. contribution ℓileft(θ)=logwc(θ)+logF(τi;θ), \ell_i^{\text{left}}(\theta) = \log w_c(\theta) + \log F(\tau_i; \theta),  wc(θ)=∫0τihc(t)S(t)dt/F(τi)w_c(\theta) = \int_0^{\tau_i} h_c(t) S(t)\, dt / F(\tau_i) candidate cause weight F(τi)=1−S(τi)F(\tau_i) = 1 - S(\tau_i). Interval-censored (ωi=interval\omega_i = \text{interval}). failure occurred known interval (ai,bi)(a_i, b_i). arises periodic inspections: system functioning time aia_i found failed time bib_i. contribution ℓiinterval(θ)=log∫aibihc(t)S(t)dt. \ell_i^{\text{interval}}(\theta) = \log \int_{a_i}^{b_i} h_c(t) S(t)\, dt. Information ordering. Intuitively, exact observations informative since pin tit_i precisely. Right-censored observations provide lower bound. Left-censored observations provide upper bound. Interval-censored observations bracket tit_i sides, typically making informative one-sided censoring: exact>interval>left≈right. \text{exact} \;>\; \text{interval} \;>\; \text{left} \approx \text{right}.  relative ranking left versus right depends hazard structure; exponential models roughly symmetric.

title: Censoring Types in Series System Masked Data
text: package provides composable observe functors translate true system failure time observed record. functor returns list elements t (observed time), omega (observation type), t_upper (upper bound, interval-censoring ). observe_mixture functor key building realistic monitoring scenarios. observation, randomly selects one constituent schemes according supplied weights. models heterogeneous monitoring environments different units observed differently—continuous monitoring, others inspected periodically. rdata() methods accept observe argument:
code: # 1. Right-censoring: continuous monitoring, study ends at tau obs_right <- observe_right_censor(tau = 10) obs_right(7)   # failure before tau -> exact #> $t #> [1] 7 #>  #> $omega #> [1] "exact" #>  #> $t_upper #> [1] NA obs_right(15)  # survival past tau  -> right-censored #> $t #> [1] 10 #>  #> $omega #> [1] "right" #>  #> $t_upper #> [1] NA  # 2. Left-censoring: single inspection at tau obs_left <- observe_left_censor(tau = 10) obs_left(7)    # failed before inspection -> left-censored #> $t #> [1] 10 #>  #> $omega #> [1] "left" #>  #> $t_upper #> [1] NA obs_left(15)   # surviving at inspection  -> right-censored #> $t #> [1] 10 #>  #> $omega #> [1] "right" #>  #> $t_upper #> [1] NA  # 3. Periodic inspection: inspections every delta, study ends at tau obs_periodic <- observe_periodic(delta = 2, tau = 10) obs_periodic(5.3)  # failure in (4, 6) -> interval-censored #> $t #> [1] 4 #>  #> $omega #> [1] "interval" #>  #> $t_upper #> [1] 6 obs_periodic(15)   # survival past tau -> right-censored #> $t #> [1] 10 #>  #> $omega #> [1] "right" #>  #> $t_upper #> [1] NA  # 4. Mixture: compose arbitrary monitoring schemes obs_mixed <- observe_mixture(   observe_right_censor(tau = 10),   observe_left_censor(tau = 5),   observe_periodic(delta = 2, tau = 10),   weights = c(0.5, 0.2, 0.3) ) model <- exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3() gen <- rdata(model) theta <- c(1, 1.1, 0.95)  set.seed(42) df <- gen(theta, n = 200, p = 0.3,           observe = observe_periodic(delta = 0.5, tau = 5)) cat("Observation type distribution:\n") #> Observation type distribution: print(table(df$omega)) #>  #> interval  #>      200

title: Censoring Types in Series System Masked Data
text: exponential model special: four observation types fully analytical log-likelihood, score, Hessian. verify small mixed-censoring example one observation type. exponential model rates λ=(0.5,0.3,0.2)\lambda = (0.5, 0.3, 0.2) λsys=1.0\lambda_{\text{sys}} = 1.0, individual contributions : Exact(t=3,c={1,2}):log(0.8)−1.0⋅3=−3.2231Right(t=8):−1.0⋅8=−8Left(τ=5,c={1,3}):log(0.7)+log(1−e−5)−log(1.0)=−0.3634Interval(=2,b=6,c={1,2}):log(0.8)−2+log(1−e−4)−log(1.0)=−2.2416\begin{align} \text{Exact}\ (t{=}3, c{=}\{1,2\}):& \quad   \log(0.8) - 1.0 \cdot 3 = -3.2231 \\ \text{Right}\ (t{=}8):& \quad   -1.0 \cdot 8 = -8 \\ \text{Left}\ (\tau{=}5, c{=}\{1,3\}):& \quad   \log(0.7) + \log(1 - e^{-5}) - \log(1.0) = -0.3634 \\ \text{Interval}\ ({=}2, b{=}6, c{=}\{1,2\}):& \quad   \log(0.8) - 2 + \log(1 - e^{-4}) - \log(1.0) = -2.2416 \end{align} Now verify analytical score consistent numerical differentiation: Score verification: analytical vs numerical agreement machine precision confirms four observation types implemented correctly exponential score.
code:
# Construct one observation of each type df_mixed <- data.frame(   t       = c(3.0,  8.0,  5.0,  2.0),   t_upper = c(NA,   NA,   NA,   6.0),   omega   = c("exact", "right", "left", "interval"),   x1      = c(TRUE,  FALSE, TRUE,  TRUE),   x2      = c(TRUE,  FALSE, FALSE, TRUE),   x3      = c(FALSE, FALSE, TRUE,  FALSE),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE ) rates <- c(0.5, 0.3, 0.2) lambda_sys <- sum(rates) exp_model <- exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3() ll_fn <- loglik(exp_model) scr_fn <- score(exp_model)  # Total log-likelihood ll_val <- ll_fn(df_mixed, rates) cat("Log-likelihood:", round(ll_val, 6), "
") #> Log-likelihood: -13.83  # Expected from hand calculation ll_exact    <- log(0.8) - lambda_sys * 3 ll_right    <- -lambda_sys * 8 ll_left     <- log(0.7) + log(-expm1(-lambda_sys * 5)) - log(lambda_sys) ll_interval <- log(0.8) - lambda_sys * 2 +   log(-expm1(-lambda_sys * 4)) - log(lambda_sys) ll_expected <- ll_exact + ll_right + ll_left + ll_interval cat("Expected:      ", round(ll_expected, 6), "
") #> Expected:       -13.83 cat("Match:", all.equal(ll_val, ll_expected, tolerance = 1e-10), "
") #> Match: TRUE scr_analytical <- scr_fn(df_mixed, rates) scr_numerical <- numDeriv::grad(   func = function(th) ll_fn(df_mixed, th),   x = rates )  score_df <- data.frame(   Component = paste0("lambda_", 1:3),   Analytical = round(scr_analytical, 6),   Numerical = round(scr_numerical, 6),   Abs_Diff = formatC(abs(scr_analytical - scr_numerical),                      format = "e", digits = 2) ) knitr::kable(score_df, caption = "Score verification: analytical vs numerical")

title: Censoring Types in Series System Masked Data
text: now study mix censoring types affects estimation quality. Using exponential model m=3m = 3 components, generate data five monitoring configurations compare bias, MSE, coverage. five configurations :
code: set.seed(7231) theta <- c(1.0, 1.1, 0.95) m <- length(theta) n <- 500 B <- 200 alpha <- 0.05  exp_model <- exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3() gen <- rdata(exp_model) solver <- fit(exp_model) theta0 <- rep(1, m)  # tau for ~25% right-censoring: solve S(tau) = 0.25 lambda_sys <- sum(theta) tau_25 <- -log(0.25) / lambda_sys  # tau for left-censoring: F(tau) ~ 0.75 -> same tau # For left_censor(tau), Pr(left) = F(tau), Pr(right) = S(tau)  configs <- list(   A = list(     name = "100% exact",     observe = observe_right_censor(tau = Inf)   ),   B = list(     name = "75% exact + 25% right",     observe = observe_right_censor(tau = tau_25)   ),   C = list(     name = "~75% left + ~25% right",     observe = observe_left_censor(tau = tau_25)   ),   D = list(     name = "mix: exact + left + interval",     observe = observe_mixture(       observe_right_censor(tau = Inf),       observe_left_censor(tau = tau_25),       observe_periodic(delta = 0.3, tau = tau_25),       weights = c(0.75, 0.125, 0.125)     )   ),   E = list(     name = "mix: all four types",     observe = observe_mixture(       observe_right_censor(tau = tau_25),       observe_left_censor(tau = tau_25),       observe_periodic(delta = 0.3, tau = tau_25),       weights = c(0.70, 0.15, 0.15)     )   ) ) sim_results <- list()  for (cfg_name in names(configs)) {   cfg <- configs[[cfg_name]]   estimates <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = m)   se_estimates <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = m)   ci_lower <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = m)   ci_upper <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = m)   converged <- logical(B)   omega_counts <- list()    for (b in 1:B) {     df_b <- gen(theta, n = n, p = 0.3, observe = cfg$observe)      if (b == 1) {       omega_counts[[cfg_name]] <- table(df_b$omega)     }      tryCatch({       result_b <- solver(df_b, par = theta0, method = "Nelder-Mead")       estimates[b, ] <- result_b$par       se_estimates[b, ] <- sqrt(diag(result_b$vcov))       z <- qnorm(1 - alpha / 2)       ci_lower[b, ] <- result_b$par - z * se_estimates[b, ]       ci_upper[b, ] <- result_b$par + z * se_estimates[b, ]       converged[b] <- result_b$converged     }, error = function(e) {       converged[b] <<- FALSE     })   }    valid <- converged & !is.na(estimates[, 1])   est_valid <- estimates[valid, , drop = FALSE]    bias <- colMeans(est_valid) - theta   variance <- apply(est_valid, 2, var)   mse <- bias^2 + variance    coverage <- numeric(m)   for (j in 1:m) {     valid_j <- valid & !is.na(ci_lower[, j])     covered <- ci_lower[valid_j, j] <= theta[j] &       theta[j] <= ci_upper[valid_j, j]     coverage[j] <- mean(covered)   }    sim_results[[cfg_name]] <- list(     name = cfg$name,     bias = bias,     variance = variance,     mse = mse,     coverage = coverage,     mean_mse = mean(mse),     mean_coverage = mean(coverage),     convergence_rate = mean(converged),     omega_sample = if (length(omega_counts) > 0) omega_counts[[cfg_name]] else NULL   ) }

title: Masked Data Likelihood Model: Components with Exponentially Distributed Lifetimes Arranged In Series Configuration
text: set solutions MLE equations must stationary points, .e., point score function type ℝm↦ℝm\mathbb{R}^m \mapsto \mathbb{R}^m zero. jj-th component output score function given ∂ℓ∂λp=∑=1n(∑j∈ciλj)−11{p∈ci δi=0}−∑=1nsi.\begin{equation} \label{eq:score_expo_j} \frac{\partial \ell}{\partial \lambda_p} =    \sum_{=1}^{n} \biggl( \sum_{j \c_i} \lambda_j \biggr)^{-1}   1_{\{p \c_i \text{ } \delta_i = 0\}} - \sum_{=1}^{n} s_i. \end{equation} may find MLE solving maximum likelihood equation , .e., set (stationary) points satisfying ∂ℓ∂λj|λ̂j=0 \frac{\partial \ell}{\partial \lambda_j}\Biggr|_{\hat\lambda_j} = 0  j=1,…,mj=1,\ldots,m. approximate solution problem using iterative Newton-Raphson method described Section . Newton-Raphson method needs observed information matrix, function λ\lambda type ℝm↦ℝm×m\mathbb{R}^m \mapsto \mathbb{R}^{m \times m}. (j,k)(j,k)-th element J(λ)J(\lambda) given ∂2ℓ∂λj∂λk=∑=1n(∑j∈ciλj)−21{j,k∈ci δi=0}.\begin{equation} \label{eq:info_expo} \frac{\partial^2 \ell}{\partial \lambda_j \partial \lambda_k} =    \sum_{=1}^{n} \biggl( \sum_{j \c_i} \lambda_j \biggr)^{-2}   1_{\{j,k \c_i \text{ } \delta_i = 0\}}. \end{equation}

what: Log-likelihood of θ\theta given masked data
title: Masked Data Likelihood Model: Components with Exponentially Distributed Lifetimes Arranged In Series Configuration
text: reduced log-likelihood function (log kernel likelihood function) given ℓ(θ|data)=−(∑=1nti)(∑j=1mθj)+∑=1n(1−δi)log(∑j∈ciθj). \ell(\theta|\text{data}) =     -\left(\sum_{=1}^{n} t_i\right)     \left(\sum_{j=1}^{m} \theta_j\right) +     \sum_{=1}^{n} (1-\delta_i)\log\left(\sum_{j \c_i} \theta_j\right). compute log-likelihood function using generic dispatch: returned function ll(df, par) evaluates log-likelihood parameter par given data df. example, true parameter value: Note implementation uses minimally sufficient statistics, improves computational efficiency. log-likelihood function contains maximum amount information parameter θ\theta given sample masked data data satisfying conditions C1C_1, C2C_2, C3C_3. Suppose know θ=(1,1.1,0.95,1.15,1.1)′\theta = (1, 1.1, 0.95, 1.15, 1.1)'. log-likelihood, may estimate θ\theta θ̂\hat\theta solving θ̂=argmaxθ∈Ωℓ(θ), \hat{\theta} = \operatorname{argmax}_{\theta \\Omega} \ell(\theta),  .e., finding point maximizes log-likelihood observed sample data. known maximum likelihood estimation (MLE). typically solve MLE solving ∇ℓ|θ=θ̂=0. \nabla \ell|_{\theta=\hat{\theta}} = 0. popular choice gradient ascent, iterative method based update rule θ(n+1)=θn+ηℓ(θn), \theta^{(n+1)} = \theta^n + \eta \ell(\theta^n),  η\eta learning rate. can also obtain score (gradient) function via generic dispatch: score true parameter close zero (MLE, exactly zero): likelihood.model framework provides analytical score Hessian implementations available, falling back numerical differentiation otherwise. follows, use algebraic.mle help solve MLE equations display various properties solution. solve MLE equation, use generic fit() function, dispatches fit.likelihood_model object "likelihood_model" class. fit() function returns solver uses optim internally BFGS method default. result mle object algebraic.mle package rich accessor methods: can access specific components MLE: Recall true parameter θ=(1,1.1,0.95,1.15,1.1)′\theta = (1, 1.1, 0.95, 1.15, 1.1)'. Due sampling variability, different runs experiment result different outcomes, .e., θ̂\hat{\theta} sampling distribution. see θ̂≠θ\hat{\theta} \neq \theta, reasonably close. may measure sampling variability using variance-covariance matrix, bias, mean squared error (MSE), confidence intervals.
code:
ll <- loglik(model) ll(data, theta) #> [1] -1393 grad <- score(model) grad(data, theta) #> [1] -23.934  -4.920  -9.392 -21.984  -2.042 # Get the solver from the model using generic dispatch solver <- fit(model)  # Solve for MLE with initial guess theta0 <- rep(1, m) estimate <- solver(data, par = theta0, method = "Nelder-Mead") # Print summary with confidence intervals print(estimate) #> Maximum Likelihood Estimate (Fisherian) #> ---------------------------------------- #> Coefficients: #> [1] 0.9617 1.1049 0.9455 1.1147 1.1116 #>  #> Log-likelihood: -1392  #> Observations: 7500 # Point estimate theta.hat <- estimate$par cat("MLE:", round(theta.hat, 4), "
") #> MLE: 0.9617 1.105 0.9455 1.115 1.112  # Standard errors (sqrt of diagonal of variance-covariance matrix) cat("SE:", round(sqrt(diag(estimate$vcov)), 4), "
") #> SE: 0.0442 0.0457 0.0427 0.0449 0.0454  # Log-likelihood at MLE cat("Log-likelihood:", round(estimate$loglik, 4), "
") #> Log-likelihood: -1392

title: Masked Data Likelihood Model: Components with Exponentially Distributed Lifetimes Arranged In Series Configuration
text: likelihood model supports four observation types. arises different monitoring scheme: Exact (ω=exact\omega = \text{exact}): system failure time tt observed directly, e.g., continuous monitoring. Right-censored (ω=right\omega = \text{right}): system known survived past tt, e.g., study ends failure. Left-censored (ω=left\omega = \text{left}): system known failed tt, e.g., single inspection finds failed. Interval-censored (ω=interval\omega = \text{interval}): failure occurred (t,tupper)(t, t_{\text{upper}}), e.g., periodic inspections bracket failure. exponential series system, individual-observation log-likelihood contributions : Exact:logλc−λsystRight:−λsystLeft:logλc+log(1−e−λsysτ)−logλsysInterval:logλc−λsysa+log(1−e−λsys(b−))−logλsys\begin{align} \text{Exact:} \quad & \log \lambda_c - \lambda_{\text{sys}} t \\ \text{Right:} \quad & -\lambda_{\text{sys}} t \\ \text{Left:} \quad & \log \lambda_c + \log(1 - e^{-\lambda_{\text{sys}} \tau})   - \log \lambda_{\text{sys}} \\ \text{Interval:} \quad & \log \lambda_c - \lambda_{\text{sys}}   + \log(1 - e^{-\lambda_{\text{sys}}(b - )}) - \log \lambda_{\text{sys}} \end{align} λc=∑j∈ciλj\lambda_c = \sum_{j \c_i} \lambda_j λsys=∑jλj\lambda_{\text{sys}} = \sum_j \lambda_j. left-censored contribution can interpreted logwc+logF(τ)\log w_c + \log F(\tau), wc=λc/λsysw_c = \lambda_c / \lambda_{\text{sys}} candidate cause weight F(τ)F(\tau) system CDF. exponential model one four types fully analytical loglik, score, Hessian. Weibull models require numerical integration numDeriv left/interval types.

title: Masked Data Likelihood Model: Components with Exponentially Distributed Lifetimes Arranged In Series Configuration
text: understand sampling properties MLE, conduct Monte Carlo simulation study. repeatedly: Generate masked data true model Fit likelihood model obtain θ̂\hat{\theta} Compute asymptotic confidence intervals collection estimates, can compute: Bias: E[θ̂]−θ\text{E}[\hat{\theta}] - \theta Variance: Var[θ̂]\text{Var}[\hat{\theta}] MSE: E[(θ̂−θ)2]=Bias2+Var\text{E}[(\hat{\theta} - \theta)^2] = \text{Bias}^2 + \text{Var} Coverage probability: Proportion CIs containing true value
code: set.seed(7231)  # Simulation parameters B <- 200       # Number of Monte Carlo replications alpha <- 0.05  # Significance level for CIs  # Storage for results estimates <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = m) se_estimates <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = m) ci_lower <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = m) ci_upper <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = m) converged <- logical(B) for (b in 1:B) {     # Generate component lifetimes     comp_times_b <- matrix(nrow = n, ncol = m)     for (j in 1:m) {         comp_times_b[, j] <- rexp(n, theta[j])     }     comp_times_b <- md_encode_matrix(comp_times_b, "t")      # Apply masking pipeline     data_b <- comp_times_b %>%         md_series_lifetime_right_censoring(tau) %>%         md_bernoulli_cand_c1_c2_c3(p) %>%         md_cand_sampler()     data_b$omega <- ifelse(data_b$delta, "exact", "right")      # Fit model     tryCatch({         result_b <- solver(data_b, par = theta0, method = "Nelder-Mead")         estimates[b, ] <- result_b$par         se_estimates[b, ] <- sqrt(diag(result_b$vcov))          # Asymptotic Wald CIs         z <- qnorm(1 - alpha/2)         ci_lower[b, ] <- result_b$par - z * sqrt(diag(result_b$vcov))         ci_upper[b, ] <- result_b$par + z * sqrt(diag(result_b$vcov))         converged[b] <- result_b$converged     }, error = function(e) {         converged[b] <<- FALSE     }) }  cat("Convergence rate:", mean(converged, na.rm = TRUE), "\n")

text: Monte Carlo Results: Bias, Variance, MSE
code: # Compute summary statistics (only for converged runs) valid <- converged & !is.na(estimates[, 1]) est_valid <- estimates[valid, , drop = FALSE]  bias <- colMeans(est_valid) - theta variance <- apply(est_valid, 2, var) mse <- bias^2 + variance rmse <- sqrt(mse)  # Create results table results_df <- data.frame(     Component = 1:m,     True = theta,     Mean_Est = colMeans(est_valid),     Bias = bias,     Variance = variance,     MSE = mse,     RMSE = rmse,     Rel_Bias_Pct = 100 * bias / theta )  knitr::kable(results_df, digits = 4,              caption = "Monte Carlo Results: Bias, Variance, and MSE",              col.names = c("Component", "True θ", "Mean θ̂", "Bias",                           "Variance", "MSE", "RMSE", "Rel. Bias %"))

text: asymptotic (1−α)(1-\alpha)% Wald confidence interval : θ̂j±z1−α/2⋅SE(θ̂j) \hat{\theta}_j \pm z_{1-\alpha/2} \cdot \text{SE}(\hat{\theta}_j) assess coverage probability: proportion intervals contain true parameter value. Coverage Probability 95% Confidence Intervals
code: # Compute coverage for each component coverage <- numeric(m) for (j in 1:m) {     valid_j <- valid & !is.na(ci_lower[, j]) & !is.na(ci_upper[, j])     covered <- (ci_lower[valid_j, j] <= theta[j]) & (theta[j] <= ci_upper[valid_j, j])     coverage[j] <- mean(covered) }  # Mean CI width mean_width <- colMeans(ci_upper[valid, ] - ci_lower[valid, ], na.rm = TRUE)  coverage_df <- data.frame(     Component = 1:m,     True = theta,     Coverage = coverage,     Nominal = 1 - alpha,     Mean_Width = mean_width )  knitr::kable(coverage_df, digits = 4,              caption = paste0("Coverage Probability of ", 100*(1-alpha), "% Confidence Intervals"),              col.names = c("Component", "True θ", "Coverage", "Nominal", "Mean Width"))

title: Masked Data Likelihood Model: Components with Exponentially Distributed Lifetimes Arranged In Series Configuration
text: Monte Carlo simulation (n=7500n = 7500, B=200B = 200, p=0.3p = 0.3, ∼25%\sim 25\% censoring) demonstrates MLE exponential series system masked data satisfying conditions C1–C3 desirable large-sample properties: Essentially unbiased. relative biases 0.7%, largest component 5 0.67%. squared-bias contribution MSE negligible (e.g., component 1: bias2≈2×10−7\text{bias}^2 \approx 2 \times 10^{-7} vs Var=0.0019\text{Var} = 0.0019). MLE consistent approximately unbiased sample size. Uniform relative precision. RMSE ranges 0.043 0.046 across components — roughly 4–5% true rates. uniformity consistent asymptotic efficiency MLE: components higher failure rates (thus higher variance) also proportionally wider CIs. Coverage near nominal. Coverage ranges 93.4% 96.5% nominal 95%. Component 4 (93.4%) slightly undercovers, suggesting Wald interval may mildly liberal components sample size. known finite-sample property Wald intervals rate parameters. CI width design metric. Mean CI widths 0.170–0.180 (±8.5%\pm 8.5\% true rate) provide concrete basis sample size planning. Since CI width scales 1/n1/\sqrt{n}, halving width requires roughly 4×4\times sample size.

title: Masked Data Likelihood Model: Components with Exponentially Distributed Lifetimes Arranged In Series Configuration
text: MLE properties depend several factors: sample size, masking probability, right-censoring rate. section, study factors affect estimation accuracy.

title: Masked Data Likelihood Model: Components with Exponentially Distributed Lifetimes Arranged In Series Configuration
text: masking probability pp controls much information failed component obscured. p=0p = 0, failed component candidate set (perfect information). pp increases, non-failed components included, making estimation difficult.  Effect Masking Probability Estimation Accuracy simulation reveals several patterns masking degrades estimation quality: MSE increases monotonically 0.015 (p=0p = 0) 0.062 (p=0.5p = 0.5) — 4.2×4.2\times degradation. RMSE roughly doubles 0.12 0.25, meaning typical estimation error doubles moving unmasked maximally masked candidate sets. Variance drives degradation, bias. Mean |bias||\text{bias}| fluctuates 0.008 0.026 systematic trend, variance grows steadily pp. consistent theoretical result conditions C1–C3 preserve unbiasedness MLE — masking erodes precision without introducing systematic error. marginal cost masking accelerates. MSE roughly doubles p=0p = 0 p=0.3p = 0.3 (0.015→0.0330.015 \0.033), roughly doubles p=0.3p = 0.3 p=0.5p = 0.5 (0.033→0.0620.033 \0.062). practitioners, means moderate masking (p≤0.3p \leq 0.3) far less costly heavy masking. Residual MSE p=0p = 0. Even masking non-failed components, MSE 0.015 remains due right-censoring alone — useful baseline isolating censoring contribution.
code: set.seed(7231)  # Use smaller sample for sensitivity study n_sens <- 500 B_sens <- 100  # Masking probabilities to test p_values <- seq(0, 0.5, by = 0.1)  # Fixed right-censoring (25% censored) q_sens <- 0.25 tau_sens <- rep(-(1/sum(theta))*log(q_sens), n_sens)  # Storage mask_results <- list() for (p_idx in seq_along(p_values)) {     p_curr <- p_values[p_idx]     est_p <- matrix(NA, nrow = B_sens, ncol = m)      for (b in 1:B_sens) {         # Generate data         comp_b <- matrix(nrow = n_sens, ncol = m)         for (j in 1:m) comp_b[, j] <- rexp(n_sens, theta[j])         comp_b <- md_encode_matrix(comp_b, "t")          data_b <- comp_b %>%             md_series_lifetime_right_censoring(tau_sens) %>%             md_bernoulli_cand_c1_c2_c3(p_curr) %>%             md_cand_sampler()         data_b$omega <- ifelse(data_b$delta, "exact", "right")          tryCatch({             fit_b <- solver(data_b, par = theta0, method = "Nelder-Mead")             if (fit_b$converged) est_p[b, ] <- fit_b$par         }, error = function(e) NULL)     }      # Compute statistics     valid_p <- !is.na(est_p[, 1])     mask_results[[p_idx]] <- list(         p = p_curr,         bias = colMeans(est_p[valid_p, , drop = FALSE]) - theta,         variance = apply(est_p[valid_p, , drop = FALSE], 2, var),         mse = (colMeans(est_p[valid_p, , drop = FALSE]) - theta)^2 +               apply(est_p[valid_p, , drop = FALSE], 2, var)     ) } # Extract bias and MSE for plotting bias_mat <- sapply(mask_results, function(x) mean(abs(x$bias))) mse_mat <- sapply(mask_results, function(x) mean(x$mse))  par(mfrow = c(1, 2), mar = c(4, 4, 2, 1))  # Mean absolute bias vs masking probability plot(p_values, bias_mat, type = "b", pch = 19, col = "blue",      xlab = "Masking Probability (p)",      ylab = "Mean Absolute Bias",      main = "Bias vs Masking Probability") grid()  # Mean MSE vs masking probability plot(p_values, mse_mat, type = "b", pch = 19, col = "red",      xlab = "Masking Probability (p)",      ylab = "Mean MSE",      main = "MSE vs Masking Probability") grid() mask_df <- data.frame(     p = p_values,     Mean_Abs_Bias = bias_mat,     Mean_MSE = mse_mat,     Mean_RMSE = sqrt(mse_mat) )  knitr::kable(mask_df, digits = 4,              caption = "Effect of Masking Probability on Estimation Accuracy",              col.names = c("Masking Prob.", "Mean |Bias|", "Mean MSE", "Mean RMSE"))

title: Masked Data Likelihood Model: Components with Exponentially Distributed Lifetimes Arranged In Series Configuration
text: Right-censoring reduces number exact failure times observed. system right-censored, know system survived beyond censoring time, don’t observe actual failure time failed component.  Effect Right-Censoring Rate Estimation Accuracy simulation reveals censoring dominant source information loss model: MSE grows 0.019 (10% censored) 0.183 (90% censored) — 9.5×9.5\times degradation, far exceeding 4.2×4.2\times range masking. Censoring damaging eliminates failure time candidate set, whereas masking dilutes candidate set. Clear inflection around 50% censoring. MSE still manageable 50% (0.0400.040) jumps 0.0590.059 70% 0.1830.183 90%. relationship censoring rate MSE convex — additional percentage point censoring damaging last. Bias remains modest even extreme censoring. Mean |bias||\text{bias}| grows 0.005 (10% censoring) 0.034 (90% censoring) stays small relative true rates (∼3%\sim 3\% worst). MLE remains approximately unbiased — consistent increasingly inefficient. Robustness extreme censoring. 90% censoring, ∼50\sim 50 500 observations exact failures, yet MLE still converges. resulting estimates imprecise (RMSE ≈0.43\approx 0.43, ∼40%\sim 40\% true rates), likelihood-based approach remains functional.
code: set.seed(7231)  # Censoring quantiles (proportion surviving past tau) # q = 0.1 means 10% survive past tau (light censoring, ~10% censored) # q = 0.9 means 90% survive past tau (heavy censoring, ~90% censored) q_values <- seq(0.1, 0.9, by = 0.1)  # Survival probabilities (matches simulation framework)  # Fixed masking probability p_cens <- 0.2  # Storage cens_results <- list() for (q_idx in seq_along(q_values)) {     q_curr <- q_values[q_idx]     tau_curr <- rep(-(1/sum(theta))*log(q_curr), n_sens)     est_q <- matrix(NA, nrow = B_sens, ncol = m)      for (b in 1:B_sens) {         # Generate data         comp_b <- matrix(nrow = n_sens, ncol = m)         for (j in 1:m) comp_b[, j] <- rexp(n_sens, theta[j])         comp_b <- md_encode_matrix(comp_b, "t")          data_b <- comp_b %>%             md_series_lifetime_right_censoring(tau_curr) %>%             md_bernoulli_cand_c1_c2_c3(p_cens) %>%             md_cand_sampler()         data_b$omega <- ifelse(data_b$delta, "exact", "right")          tryCatch({             fit_b <- solver(data_b, par = theta0, method = "Nelder-Mead")             if (fit_b$converged) est_q[b, ] <- fit_b$par         }, error = function(e) NULL)     }      # Compute statistics     valid_q <- !is.na(est_q[, 1])     cens_rate <- mean(data_b$omega == "right")  # Actual censoring rate     cens_results[[q_idx]] <- list(         q = q_curr,         cens_rate = cens_rate,         bias = colMeans(est_q[valid_q, , drop = FALSE]) - theta,         variance = apply(est_q[valid_q, , drop = FALSE], 2, var),         mse = (colMeans(est_q[valid_q, , drop = FALSE]) - theta)^2 +               apply(est_q[valid_q, , drop = FALSE], 2, var)     ) } # Extract statistics cens_rates <- sapply(cens_results, function(x) x$cens_rate) bias_cens <- sapply(cens_results, function(x) mean(abs(x$bias))) mse_cens <- sapply(cens_results, function(x) mean(x$mse))  par(mfrow = c(1, 2), mar = c(4, 4, 2, 1))  # Mean absolute bias vs censoring rate plot(cens_rates * 100, bias_cens, type = "b", pch = 19, col = "blue",      xlab = "Censoring Rate (%)",      ylab = "Mean Absolute Bias",      main = "Bias vs Censoring Rate") grid()  # Mean MSE vs censoring rate plot(cens_rates * 100, mse_cens, type = "b", pch = 19, col = "red",      xlab = "Censoring Rate (%)",      ylab = "Mean MSE",      main = "MSE vs Censoring Rate") grid() cens_df <- data.frame(     Cens_Rate_Pct = round(cens_rates * 100, 1),     Mean_Abs_Bias = bias_cens,     Mean_MSE = mse_cens,     Mean_RMSE = sqrt(mse_cens) )  knitr::kable(cens_df, digits = 4,              caption = "Effect of Right-Censoring Rate on Estimation Accuracy",              col.names = c("Censoring %", "Mean |Bias|", "Mean MSE", "Mean RMSE"))

title: Masked Data Likelihood Model: Components with Exponentially Distributed Lifetimes Arranged In Series Configuration
text: Based sensitivity analyses: Prioritize reducing censoring masking. Censoring degrades MSE 9.5×9.5\times across range versus 4.2×4.2\times masking. experimental design, extending observation window reduce censoring 50% yields larger gains improving diagnostic resolution reduce masking. Moderate masking tolerable. title: Homogeneous Weibull Series Systems: Shared Shape Parameter
text: Consider series system mm components component lifetime follows Weibull distribution common shape parameter kk individual scale parameters β1,…,βm\beta_1, \ldots, \beta_m. parameter vector θ=(k,β1,…,βm)∈ℝ>0m+1.   \theta = (k, \beta_1, \ldots, \beta_m) \\mathbb{R}^{m+1}_{>0}. jj-th component hazard function hj(t∣k,βj)=kβj(tβj)k−1,t>0,   h_j(t \mid k, \beta_j) = \frac{k}{\beta_j}     \left(\frac{t}{\beta_j}\right)^{k-1}, \quad t > 0,  survival function Rj(t∣k,βj)=exp(−(tβj)k),   R_j(t \mid k, \beta_j) = \exp\!\left(-\left(\frac{t}{\beta_j}\right)^k\right),  pdf fj(t∣k,βj)=hj(t)Rj(t)=kβj(tβj)k−1exp(−(tβj)k).   f_j(t \mid k, \beta_j) = h_j(t) \, R_j(t)     = \frac{k}{\beta_j}\left(\frac{t}{\beta_j}\right)^{k-1}       \exp\!\left(-\left(\frac{t}{\beta_j}\right)^k\right). shape parameter kk controls failure rate behaviour: k<1k < 1: decreasing failure rate (DFR) – infant mortality, burn-k=1k = 1: constant failure rate (CFR) – exponential distribution k>1k > 1: increasing failure rate (IFR) – wear-, aging

title: Homogeneous Weibull Series Systems: Shared Shape Parameter
text: system lifetime T=min(T1,…,Tm)T = \min(T_1, \ldots, T_m) reliability Rsys(t∣θ)=∏j=1mRj(t)=exp(−∑j=1m(tβj)k).   R_{\text{sys}}(t \mid \theta) = \prod_{j=1}^m R_j(t)     = \exp\!\left(-\sum_{j=1}^m \left(\frac{t}{\beta_j}\right)^k\right). components share shape kk, exponent simplifies: ∑j=1m(tβj)k=tk∑j=1mβj−k=(tβsys)k,   \sum_{j=1}^m \left(\frac{t}{\beta_j}\right)^k     = t^k \sum_{j=1}^m \beta_j^{-k}     = \left(\frac{t}{\beta_{\text{sys}}}\right)^k,  βsys=(∑j=1mβj−k)−1/k.   \beta_{\text{sys}} = \left(\sum_{j=1}^m \beta_j^{-k}\right)^{-1/k}.  Thus, system lifetime Weibull shape kk scale βsys\beta_{\text{sys}}: T∼Weibull(k,βsys).   T \sim \operatorname{Weibull}(k, \beta_{\text{sys}}).  closure minimum operation defining structural advantage homogeneous model computed wei_series_system_scale(k, scales).

P(K = j \mid T = t, \theta) = \frac{h_j(t)}{h_{\text{sys}}(t)}     = \frac{\beta_j^{-k} \cdot (k / \beta_j)(t/\beta_j)^{k-1}}            {\sum_l \beta_l^{-k} \cdot (k / \beta_l)(t/\beta_l)^{k-1}}.  tk−1t^{k-1} kk factors cancel, yielding P(K=j∣T=t,θ)=βj−k∑l=1mβl−k≕wj.   P(K = j \mid T = t, \theta) = \frac{\beta_j^{-k}}{\sum_{l=1}^m \beta_l^{-k}}     \eqqcolon w_j. title: Homogeneous Weibull Series Systems: Shared Shape Parameter
text: score function uses hybrid approach: analytical gradients exact right-censored observations, numDeriv::grad left- interval-censored observations. Hessian fully numerical, computed Jacobian score via numDeriv::jacobian.
code:
ll_fn <- loglik(model) scr_fn <- score(model) hess_fn <- hess_loglik(model)  # Score at MLE should be near zero scr_mle <- scr_fn(df, estimate$par) cat("Score at MLE:", round(scr_mle, 4), "
") #> Score at MLE: -0.141 -0.0018 -1e-04 -2e-04  # Verify score against numerical gradient scr_num <- numDeriv::grad(function(th) ll_fn(df, th), estimate$par) cat("Max |analytical - numerical| score:",     formatC(max(abs(scr_mle - scr_num)), format = "e", digits = 2), "
") #> Max |analytical - numerical| score: 0.00e+00  # Hessian eigenvalues (should be negative for concavity) H <- hess_fn(df, estimate$par) cat("Hessian eigenvalues:", round(eigen(H)$values, 2), "
") #> Hessian eigenvalues: -431 -0.05 -0.01 0

title: Homogeneous Weibull Series Systems: Shared Shape Parameter
text: compare estimation performance across three shape regimes: decreasing failure rate (k=0.7k = 0.7), constant (k=1.0k = 1.0), increasing (k=1.5k = 1.5). scenario uses m=3m = 3 components, n=500n = 500 observations, Bernoulli masking p=0.3p = 0.3, periodic inspection approximately 25% right-censoring.
code: set.seed(2024)  B <- 100          # Monte Carlo replications n_mc <- 500       # Sample size per replication p_mc <- 0.3       # Masking probability alpha <- 0.05     # CI level  # Three shape regimes scenarios <- list(   DFR = c(k = 0.7, beta1 = 100, beta2 = 150, beta3 = 200),   CFR = c(k = 1.0, beta1 = 100, beta2 = 150, beta3 = 200),   IFR = c(k = 1.5, beta1 = 100, beta2 = 150, beta3 = 200) )  results <- list() model_mc <- wei_series_homogeneous_md_c1_c2_c3() gen_mc <- rdata(model_mc) solver_mc <- fit(model_mc)  for (sc_name in names(scenarios)) {   th <- scenarios[[sc_name]]   k_sc <- th[1]   scales_sc <- th[-1]   m_sc <- length(scales_sc)   npars <- m_sc + 1    # Choose tau to give ~25% right-censoring   beta_sys_sc <- wei_series_system_scale(k_sc, scales_sc)   tau_sc <- qweibull(0.75, shape = k_sc, scale = beta_sys_sc)   delta_sc <- tau_sc / 10  # ~10 inspection intervals    estimates <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = npars)   se_est <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = npars)   ci_lower <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = npars)   ci_upper <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = npars)   converged <- logical(B)   cens_fracs <- numeric(B)    for (b in seq_len(B)) {     df_b <- gen_mc(th, n = n_mc, p = p_mc,                    observe = observe_periodic(delta = delta_sc, tau = tau_sc))     cens_fracs[b] <- mean(df_b$omega == "right")      tryCatch({       est_b <- solver_mc(df_b, par = c(1, rep(120, m_sc)),                          method = "L-BFGS-B",                          lower = rep(1e-6, npars))       estimates[b, ] <- est_b$par       se_est[b, ] <- sqrt(diag(est_b$vcov))       z <- qnorm(1 - alpha / 2)       ci_lower[b, ] <- est_b$par - z * se_est[b, ]       ci_upper[b, ] <- est_b$par + z * se_est[b, ]       converged[b] <- est_b$converged     }, error = function(e) {       converged[b] <<- FALSE     })   }    results[[sc_name]] <- list(     theta = th, estimates = estimates, se_est = se_est,     ci_lower = ci_lower, ci_upper = ci_upper,     converged = converged, cens_fracs = cens_fracs,     tau = tau_sc, delta = delta_sc   ) }

what: Bias and MSE by shape regime
title: Homogeneous Weibull Series Systems: Shared Shape Parameter
text: Monte Carlo Results Shape Regime (B=100, n=500)
code: summary_rows <- list()  for (sc_name in names(results)) {   res <- results[[sc_name]]   th <- res$theta   valid <- res$converged & !is.na(res$estimates[, 1])   est_v <- res$estimates[valid, , drop = FALSE]    bias <- colMeans(est_v) - th   variance <- apply(est_v, 2, var)   mse <- bias^2 + variance   pnames <- c("k", paste0("beta", seq_along(th[-1])))    for (j in seq_along(th)) {     summary_rows[[length(summary_rows) + 1]] <- data.frame(       Regime = sc_name,       Parameter = pnames[j],       True = th[j],       Mean_Est = mean(est_v[, j]),       Bias = bias[j],       RMSE = sqrt(mse[j]),       Rel_Bias_Pct = 100 * bias[j] / th[j],       stringsAsFactors = FALSE     )   } }  mc_table <- do.call(rbind, summary_rows)  knitr::kable(mc_table, digits = 3, row.names = FALSE,              caption = "Monte Carlo Results by Shape Regime (B=100, n=500)",              col.names = c("Regime", "Parameter", "True", "Mean Est.",                           "Bias", "RMSE", "Rel. Bias %"))

title: Homogeneous Weibull Series Systems: Shared Shape Parameter
text: 95% Wald CI Coverage Shape Regime
code: coverage_rows <- list()  for (sc_name in names(results)) {   res <- results[[sc_name]]   th <- res$theta   valid <- res$converged & !is.na(res$ci_lower[, 1])   pnames <- c("k", paste0("beta", seq_along(th[-1])))    for (j in seq_along(th)) {     valid_j <- valid & !is.na(res$ci_lower[, j]) & !is.na(res$ci_upper[, j])     covered <- (res$ci_lower[valid_j, j] <= th[j]) &                (th[j] <= res$ci_upper[valid_j, j])     width <- mean(res$ci_upper[valid_j, j] - res$ci_lower[valid_j, j])      coverage_rows[[length(coverage_rows) + 1]] <- data.frame(       Regime = sc_name,       Parameter = pnames[j],       Coverage = mean(covered),       Mean_Width = width,       stringsAsFactors = FALSE     )   } }  cov_table <- do.call(rbind, coverage_rows)  knitr::kable(cov_table, digits = 3, row.names = FALSE,              caption = "95% Wald CI Coverage by Shape Regime",              col.names = c("Regime", "Parameter", "Coverage", "Mean Width"))

title: Homogeneous Weibull Series Systems: Shared Shape Parameter
text: Monte Carlo study reveals several patterns: Shape estimation accuracy varies regime. IFR regime (k=1.5k = 1.5) produces precise shape estimates increasing hazards generate failures early, providing richer information. DFR regime (k=0.7k = 0.7) widest shape CIs decreasing hazards spread failures longer horizon. Scale estimation robust across regimes. Relative bias scale parameters typically 5% three regimes, coverage near nominal 95%. scale parameters well-identified regardless shape value. Periodic inspection adds interval-censoring. Unlike exponential vignette used exact + right observations, study uses periodic inspection. closed-form interval-censored contributions (unique homogeneous model) keep computation fast despite additional complexity.

title: Homogeneous Weibull Series Systems: Shared Shape Parameter
text: k=1k = 1, homogeneous Weibull model reduces exponential model. verify numerically comparing log-likelihoods data. two log-likelihoods agree machine precision, confirming homogeneous Weibull model proper generalization exponential series model. also serves consistency check implementation. transformed Weibull scores match exponential scores, confirming two parameterizations yield identical inference k=1k = 1.
code:
# Parameters: k=1 with scales equivalent to rates (1/beta_j) exp_rates <- c(0.01, 0.008, 0.005) wei_scales <- 1 / exp_rates  # beta = 1/lambda wei_theta <- c(1, wei_scales)  # Generate data under exponential model exp_model <- exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3() exp_gen <- rdata(exp_model)  set.seed(42) df_test <- exp_gen(exp_rates, n = 200, tau = 300, p = 0.3)  # Evaluate both log-likelihoods ll_exp <- loglik(exp_model) ll_wei <- loglik(model)  val_exp <- ll_exp(df_test, exp_rates) val_wei <- ll_wei(df_test, wei_theta)  cat("Exponential loglik:", round(val_exp, 6), "
") #> Exponential loglik: -1104 cat("Weibull(k=1) loglik:", round(val_wei, 6), "
") #> Weibull(k=1) loglik: -1104 cat("Absolute difference:", formatC(abs(val_exp - val_wei),                                      format = "e", digits = 2), "
") #> Absolute difference: 2.27e-13 # Score comparison s_exp <- score(exp_model)(df_test, exp_rates) s_wei <- score(model)(df_test, wei_theta)  # The exponential score is d/d(lambda_j), the Weibull score includes d/dk # and d/d(beta_j). At k=1, d/d(beta_j) = -(1/beta_j^2) * d/d(lambda_j) # We compare the scale scores after chain-rule transformation s_wei_transformed <- -s_wei[-1] / wei_scales^2  cat("Exponential score:        ", round(s_exp, 4), "
") #> Exponential score:         -1490 -395 -439.4 cat("Weibull(k=1) scale score: ", round(s_wei_transformed, 4), "
") #> Weibull(k=1) scale score:  0 0 0 cat("Max |difference|:",     formatC(max(abs(s_exp - s_wei_transformed)), format = "e", digits = 2), "
") #> Max |difference|: 1.49e+03

title: Heterogeneous Weibull Series Systems: Flexible Hazard Shapes
text: Real engineered systems composed components fundamentally different failure mechanisms. Consider pumping station three subsystems: Electronic controller – dominated early-life defects (solder joints, capacitor infant mortality). hazard rate decreases time weak units weeded . decreasing failure rate (DFR), modeled Weibull shape k<1k < 1. Seals gaskets – random shocks chemical degradation produce failures roughly constant rate component’s useful life. constant failure rate (CFR), corresponding k=1k = 1 (exponential). Mechanical bearing – progressive wear-causes hazard rate increase time. increasing failure rate (IFR), modeled Weibull shape k>1k > 1. exponential series model forces kj=1k_j = 1 every component, collapsing three mechanisms single constant-hazard regime. homogeneous Weibull model (wei_series_homogeneous_md_c1_c2_c3) allows k≠1k \neq 1 constrains components share common shape — still restrictive failure physics differ across subsystems. heterogeneous Weibull series model (wei_series_md_c1_c2_c3) removes constraint entirely. mm components shape scale: Tij∼Weibull(kj,βj),j=1,…,m, T_{ij} \sim \operatorname{Weibull}(k_j, \beta_j), \quad j = 1, \ldots, m,  giving 2m2m-dimensional parameter vector θ=(k1,β1,…,km,βm)\theta = (k_1, \beta_1, \ldots, k_m, \beta_m). shapes equal (k1=⋯=km=kk_1 = \cdots = k_m = k), model reduces homogeneous case, making heterogeneous model strict generalization. additional flexibility comes cost: system lifetime T=min(T1,…,Tm)T = \min(T_1, \ldots, T_m) longer Weibull-distributed shapes differ, left-censored interval-censored likelihood contributions require numerical integration rather closed-form expressions. vignette demonstrates full workflow: hazard profiling, data generation, MLE mixed censoring, model comparison, Monte Carlo assessment estimator properties.

text: Weibull hazard component jj hj(t;kj,βj)=kjβj(tβj)kj−1,t>0. h_j(t; k_j, \beta_j) = \frac{k_j}{\beta_j}   \left(\frac{t}{\beta_j}\right)^{k_j - 1}, \quad t > 0. extract component hazard closures model object plot :  DFR component (blue) hazard starts high decays – typical infant-mortality failures. CFR component (green) flat, consistent random shocks. IFR component (red) rises steadily, reflecting wear-. system hazard h(t)=∑jhj(t)h(t) = \sum_j h_j(t) vertical sum curves.
code: model <- wei_series_md_c1_c2_c3(   shapes = theta[seq(1, 6, 2)],   scales = theta[seq(2, 6, 2)] )  h1 <- component_hazard(model, 1) h2 <- component_hazard(model, 2) h3 <- component_hazard(model, 3)  t_grid <- seq(0.5, 120, length.out = 300)  plot(t_grid, h1(t_grid, theta), type = "l", col = "steelblue", lwd = 2,      ylim = c(0, 0.05),      xlab = "Time", ylab = "Hazard rate h(t)",      main = "Component hazard functions") lines(t_grid, h2(t_grid, theta), col = "forestgreen", lwd = 2, lty = 2) lines(t_grid, h3(t_grid, theta), col = "firebrick", lwd = 2, lty = 3) legend("topright",        legend = c("Comp 1: DFR (k=0.7)", "Comp 2: CFR (k=1.0)",                   "Comp 3: IFR (k=2.0)"),        col = c("steelblue", "forestgreen", "firebrick"),        lty = 1:3, lwd = 2, cex = 0.85) grid()

title: Heterogeneous Weibull Series Systems: Flexible Hazard Shapes
text: probability component jj caused system failure, conditional failure time tt, P(K=j∣T=t,θ)=hj(t;θ)∑l=1mhl(t;θ). P(K = j \mid T = t, \theta) = \frac{h_j(t; \theta)}{\sum_{l=1}^m h_l(t; \theta)}. key quantity diagnosing failure mode dominates different points system’s life:  early times DFR component dominates hazard highest tt small. time progresses IFR component takes , eventually accounting majority failures. CFR component contributes roughly constant share. crossover pattern characteristic bathtub-curve behavior system level captured models force common shape parameter.
code: ccp_fn <- conditional_cause_probability(model)  probs <- ccp_fn(t_grid, theta)  plot(t_grid, probs[, 1], type = "l", col = "steelblue", lwd = 2,      ylim = c(0, 1),      xlab = "Time", ylab = "P(K = j | T = t)",      main = "Conditional cause-of-failure probability") lines(t_grid, probs[, 2], col = "forestgreen", lwd = 2, lty = 2) lines(t_grid, probs[, 3], col = "firebrick", lwd = 2, lty = 3) legend("right",        legend = c("Comp 1: DFR", "Comp 2: CFR", "Comp 3: IFR"),        col = c("steelblue", "forestgreen", "firebrick"),        lty = 1:3, lwd = 2, cex = 0.85) grid()

title: Heterogeneous Weibull Series Systems: Flexible Hazard Shapes
text: exact right-censored observations, Weibull log-likelihood contribution closed form regardless whether shapes heterogeneous: Exact:log∑j∈cihj(ti)−∑l=1mHl(ti),Right:−∑l=1mHl(ti),\begin{align} \text{Exact:} \quad & \log \sum_{j \c_i} h_j(t_i) - \sum_{l=1}^m H_l(t_i), \\ \text{Right:} \quad & -\sum_{l=1}^m H_l(t_i), \end{align} Hl(t)=(t/βl)klH_l(t) = (t/\beta_l)^{k_l} cumulative hazard component ll. left-censored interval-censored observations, contribution involves integrating “candidate-weighted” density interval: ℓi=log∫ab[∑j∈cihj(u)]exp(−∑l=1mHl(u))du. \ell_i = \log \int_a^b \left[\sum_{j \c_i} h_j(u)\right]   \exp\!\left(-\sum_{l=1}^m H_l(u)\right) du. shapes equal (kl=kk_l = k ll), candidate weight wc=∑j∈cβj−k/∑lβl−kw_c = \sum_{j \c} \beta_j^{-k} / \sum_l \beta_l^{-k} factors integral, leaving standard Weibull CDF difference closed form. w_c factorization homogeneous model exploits. shapes differ, factorization exists, stats::integrate used internally. integrand accessible (advanced use) via likelihood.model.series.md:::wei_series_integrand:  integrand product candidate hazard sum system survival function. integral (0,τ)(0, \tau) gives probability system fails τ\tau cause candidate set.
code: shapes <- theta[seq(1, 6, 2)] scales <- theta[seq(2, 6, 2)] cind <- c(TRUE, TRUE, FALSE)  # candidate set = {1, 2}  # Evaluate the integrand h_c(t) * S(t) at a few time points t_eval <- c(10, 50, 100) vals <- likelihood.model.series.md:::wei_series_integrand(   t_eval, shapes, scales, cind ) names(vals) <- paste0("t=", t_eval) vals #>     t=10     t=50    t=100  #> 0.012504 0.004574 0.001120 t_fine <- seq(0.5, 150, length.out = 500)  # Full candidate set: all components vals_full <- likelihood.model.series.md:::wei_series_integrand(   t_fine, shapes, scales, cind = rep(TRUE, 3) )  plot(t_fine, vals_full, type = "l", col = "black", lwd = 2,      xlab = "Time", ylab = expression(h[c](t) %.% S(t)),      main = "Weibull series integrand (full candidate set)") grid()

previous_headings: Numerical integration for left and interval censoring
title: Heterogeneous Weibull Series Systems: Flexible Hazard Shapes
text: Numerical integration adds per-observation cost. compare log-likelihood evaluation time exact-versus mixed-censoring data: slowdown proportional number left/interval observations, since requires call stats::integrate. moderate sample sizes fast enough iterative optimization.
code:
set.seed(123) gen <- rdata(model) ll_fn <- loglik(model)  # Exact + right only df_exact <- gen(theta, n = 100, tau = 120, p = 0.3,                 observe = observe_right_censor(tau = 120))  # Mixed: includes left and interval censoring df_mixed <- gen(theta, n = 100, p = 0.3,                 observe = observe_mixture(                   observe_right_censor(tau = 120),                   observe_left_censor(tau = 80),                   observe_periodic(delta = 20, tau = 120),                   weights = c(0.5, 0.25, 0.25)                 ))  cat("Observation type counts (exact/right):
") #> Observation type counts (exact/right): print(table(df_exact$omega)) #>  #> exact right  #>    97     3  cat("
Observation type counts (mixed):
") #>  #> Observation type counts (mixed): print(table(df_mixed$omega)) #>  #>    exact interval     left    right  #>       47       31       13        9  t_exact <- system.time(replicate(5, ll_fn(df_exact, theta)))["elapsed"] t_mixed <- system.time(replicate(5, ll_fn(df_mixed, theta)))["elapsed"]  cat(sprintf("
Loglik time (exact/right only): %.4f s per eval
", t_exact / 5)) #>  #> Loglik time (exact/right only): 0.0020 s per eval cat(sprintf("Loglik time (mixed censoring):  %.4f s per eval
", t_mixed / 5)) #> Loglik time (mixed censoring):  0.0474 s per eval cat(sprintf("Slowdown factor: %.1fx
", t_mixed / t_exact)) #> Slowdown factor: 23.7x

title: Heterogeneous Weibull Series Systems: Flexible Hazard Shapes
text: now demonstrate full estimation workflow: generate data mixed observation scheme, fit heterogeneous Weibull model. use right-censoring exact right-censored observations closed-form likelihood contributions, making optimization fast. Left-censored interval-censored observations require numerical integration per observation per iteration (see Section 5), MLE many observations substantially slower. practice, fit() interface regardless observation type – wall-clock time differs. Parameter recovery (n = 300) n=300n = 300 observations substantial masking (p=0.3p = 0.3), MLE recovers six parameters. Shape parameters typically estimated higher relative error scales, expected: shape controls curvature hazard, distinguishing curvature level requires information estimating level alone.
code:
set.seed(7231) n_mle <- 300  # Right-censoring only (fast, closed-form likelihood) gen <- rdata(model) df <- gen(theta, n = n_mle, tau = 120, p = 0.3,           observe = observe_right_censor(tau = 120))  cat("Observation types:
") #> Observation types: print(table(df$omega)) #>  #> exact right  #>   286    14 cat("
First few rows:
") #>  #> First few rows: print(head(df), row.names = FALSE) #>         t omega    x1    x2    x3 #>   43.5375 exact  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE #>  120.0000 right FALSE FALSE FALSE #>  109.3242 exact FALSE FALSE  TRUE #>  106.2039 exact FALSE FALSE  TRUE #>   56.8859 exact FALSE  TRUE  TRUE #>    0.5781 exact  TRUE  TRUE FALSE solver <- fit(model)  # Initial guess: all shapes = 1, scales = 100 theta0 <- rep(c(1, 100), m)  estimate <- solver(df, par = theta0, method = "Nelder-Mead") print(estimate) #> Maximum Likelihood Estimate (Fisherian) #> ---------------------------------------- #> Coefficients: #> [1]   0.6864 200.8685   1.1214 154.3711   2.3123 100.1984 #>  #> Log-likelihood: -1572  #> Observations: 300  #> WARNING: Optimization did not converge # Parameter recovery table par_names <- paste0(   rep(c("k", "beta"), m), "_",   rep(1:m, each = 2) ) recovery <- data.frame(   Parameter = par_names,   True = theta,   Estimate = estimate$par,   SE = sqrt(diag(estimate$vcov)),   Rel_Error_Pct = 100 * (estimate$par - theta) / theta )  knitr::kable(recovery, digits = 3,              caption = paste0("Parameter recovery (n = ", n_mle, ")"),              col.names = c("Parameter", "True", "MLE", "SE", "Rel. Error %"))

title: Heterogeneous Weibull Series Systems: Flexible Hazard Shapes
text: central question practice whether added complexity heterogeneous shapes justified data. compare heterogeneous model (6 parameters) homogeneous model (4 parameters: one common shape plus three scales). Model comparison: heterogeneous vs homogeneous true DGP heterogeneous shapes (0.7,1.0,2.0)(0.7, 1.0, 2.0), homogeneous model misspecified. likelihood ratio test AIC strongly favor heterogeneous model. common shape estimate homogeneous fit represents compromise value true shapes, leading biased estimates scale parameters well. Bias-variance tradeoff. sample sizes small censoring heavy, homogeneous model may still preferable despite misspecification: fewer parameters yield lower variance estimates. regimes, MSE homogeneous estimator can smaller heterogeneous estimator, even though latter unbiased. nn grows, bias homogeneous model becomes dominant error term, heterogeneous model wins.
code:
set.seed(999)  # Generate from the TRUE heterogeneous DGP df_comp <- gen(theta, n = 800, tau = 150, p = 0.2,                observe = observe_right_censor(tau = 150))  cat("Observation types:
") #> Observation types: print(table(df_comp$omega)) #>  #> exact right  #>   790    10 # Fit heterogeneous model (6 parameters) model_het <- wei_series_md_c1_c2_c3() solver_het <- fit(model_het) fit_het <- solver_het(df_comp, par = rep(c(1, 120), m), method = "Nelder-Mead")  # Fit homogeneous model (4 parameters) model_hom <- wei_series_homogeneous_md_c1_c2_c3() solver_hom <- fit(model_hom) theta0_hom <- c(1, 120, 120, 120) fit_hom <- solver_hom(df_comp, par = theta0_hom, method = "Nelder-Mead")  cat("Heterogeneous model (2m = 6 params):
") #> Heterogeneous model (2m = 6 params): cat("  Log-likelihood:", fit_het$loglik, "
") #>   Log-likelihood: -4375 cat("  Parameters:", round(fit_het$par, 2), "

") #>   Parameters: 0.85 133.2 0.93 170.5 2.22 96.6  cat("Homogeneous model (m+1 = 4 params):
") #> Homogeneous model (m+1 = 4 params): cat("  Log-likelihood:", fit_hom$loglik, "
") #>   Log-likelihood: -4451 cat("  Parameters:", round(fit_hom$par, 2), "
") #>   Parameters: 1.11 128 151.9 112.7 # Likelihood ratio test # H0: k1 = k2 = k3 (homogeneous, 4 params) # H1: k1, k2, k3 free (heterogeneous, 6 params) LRT <- 2 * (fit_het$loglik - fit_hom$loglik) df_lrt <- 6 - 4  # difference in parameters p_value <- pchisq(LRT, df = df_lrt, lower.tail = FALSE)  comparison <- data.frame(   Model = c("Heterogeneous (2m)", "Homogeneous (m+1)"),   Params = c(6, 4),   LogLik = c(fit_het$loglik, fit_hom$loglik),   AIC = c(-2 * fit_het$loglik + 2 * 6, -2 * fit_hom$loglik + 2 * 4) )  knitr::kable(comparison, digits = 2,              caption = "Model comparison: heterogeneous vs homogeneous",              col.names = c("Model", "# Params", "Log-Lik", "AIC")) cat(sprintf("
Likelihood ratio statistic: %.2f (df = %d, p = %.4f)
",             LRT, df_lrt, p_value)) #>  #> Likelihood ratio statistic: 151.83 (df = 2, p = 0.0000)

title: Heterogeneous Weibull Series Systems: Flexible Hazard Shapes
text: assess finite-sample properties MLE heterogeneous Weibull model Monte Carlo simulation. Design: True DGP: θ=(0.8,150,1.5,120,2.0,100)\theta = (0.8, 150, 1.5, 120, 2.0, 100) m=3m = 3 components 2m=62m = 6 parameters. Sample size: n=1000n = 1000. Replications: B=100B = 100. Masking probability: p=0.2p = 0.2. Right-censoring τ=200\tau = 200.
code: set.seed(42)  theta_mc <- c(0.8, 150, 1.5, 120, 2.0, 100) m_mc <- length(theta_mc) / 2 n_mc <- 1000 B <- 100 p_mc <- 0.2 tau_mc <- 200 alpha <- 0.05  model_mc <- wei_series_md_c1_c2_c3() gen_mc <- rdata(model_mc) solver_mc <- fit(model_mc)  # Storage estimates <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = 2 * m_mc) se_estimates <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = 2 * m_mc) ci_lower <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = 2 * m_mc) ci_upper <- matrix(NA, nrow = B, ncol = 2 * m_mc) converged <- logical(B) logliks <- numeric(B) theta0_mc <- rep(c(1, 130), m_mc)  for (b in seq_len(B)) {   df_b <- gen_mc(theta_mc, n = n_mc, tau = tau_mc, p = p_mc,                  observe = observe_right_censor(tau = tau_mc))    tryCatch({     fit_b <- solver_mc(df_b, par = theta0_mc, method = "Nelder-Mead")     estimates[b, ] <- fit_b$par     se_estimates[b, ] <- sqrt(diag(fit_b$vcov))     logliks[b] <- fit_b$loglik      z <- qnorm(1 - alpha / 2)     ci_lower[b, ] <- fit_b$par - z * se_estimates[b, ]     ci_upper[b, ] <- fit_b$par + z * se_estimates[b, ]     converged[b] <- fit_b$converged   }, error = function(e) {     converged[b] <<- FALSE   })    if (b %% 20 == 0) cat(sprintf("Replication %d/%d\n", b, B)) }  cat("Convergence rate:", mean(converged, na.rm = TRUE), "\n")

title: Heterogeneous Weibull Series Systems: Flexible Hazard Shapes
text: Monte Carlo results (n = 1000, B = 9 converged)
code: theta_mc <- results$theta_mc m_mc <- results$m_mc alpha <- results$alpha  valid <- results$converged & !is.na(results$estimates[, 1]) est_valid <- results$estimates[valid, , drop = FALSE]  bias <- colMeans(est_valid) - theta_mc variance <- apply(est_valid, 2, var) mse <- bias^2 + variance rmse <- sqrt(mse)  par_names_mc <- paste0(   rep(c("k", "beta"), m_mc), "_",   rep(1:m_mc, each = 2) )  results_df <- data.frame(   Parameter = par_names_mc,   True = theta_mc,   Mean_Est = colMeans(est_valid),   Bias = bias,   Variance = variance,   MSE = mse,   RMSE = rmse,   Rel_Bias_Pct = 100 * bias / theta_mc )  knitr::kable(results_df, digits = 4,              caption = paste0("Monte Carlo results (n = ", results$n_mc,                               ", B = ", sum(valid), " converged)"),              col.names = c("Parameter", "True", "Mean Est.",                           "Bias", "Variance", "MSE", "RMSE",                           "Rel. Bias %"))

title: Heterogeneous Weibull Series Systems: Flexible Hazard Shapes
text: asymptotic (1−α)(1 - \alpha)% Wald confidence interval parameter θ̂j±z1−α/2⋅SE(θ̂j), \hat\theta_j \pm z_{1-\alpha/2} \cdot \text{SE}(\hat\theta_j),  SE\text{SE} derived observed information (negative Hessian). 95% CI coverage (nominal = 0.95)
code: coverage <- numeric(2 * m_mc) for (j in seq_len(2 * m_mc)) {   valid_j <- valid & !is.na(results$ci_lower[, j]) &     !is.na(results$ci_upper[, j])   covered <- (results$ci_lower[valid_j, j] <= theta_mc[j]) &     (theta_mc[j] <= results$ci_upper[valid_j, j])   coverage[j] <- mean(covered) }  mean_width <- colMeans(   results$ci_upper[valid, ] - results$ci_lower[valid, ], na.rm = TRUE )  coverage_df <- data.frame(   Parameter = par_names_mc,   True = theta_mc,   Coverage = coverage,   Nominal = 1 - alpha,   Mean_Width = mean_width )  knitr::kable(coverage_df, digits = 4,              caption = paste0(100 * (1 - alpha),                               "% CI coverage (nominal = ",                               1 - alpha, ")"),              col.names = c("Parameter", "True", "Coverage",                           "Nominal", "Mean Width"))

title: Heterogeneous Weibull Series Systems: Flexible Hazard Shapes
code: par(mfrow = c(2, 3), mar = c(4, 4, 2, 1)) for (j in seq_len(2 * m_mc)) {   hist(est_valid[, j], breaks = 20, probability = TRUE,        main = par_names_mc[j],        xlab = expression(hat(theta)),        col = "lightblue", border = "white")   abline(v = theta_mc[j], col = "red", lwd = 2, lty = 2)   abline(v = mean(est_valid[, j]), col = "blue", lwd = 2)   legend("topright", legend = c("True", "Mean"),          col = c("red", "blue"), lty = c(2, 1), lwd = 2, cex = 0.7) }

title: Heterogeneous Weibull Series Systems: Flexible Hazard Shapes
text: Monte Carlo simulation (n=1000n = 1000, B=9B = 9 converged, p=0.2p = 0.2) demonstrates following properties heterogeneous Weibull MLE: Shape parameters harder estimate scales. relative bias RMSE shape parameters (k1,k2,k3)(k_1, k_2, k_3) typically larger corresponding scales (β1,β2,β3)(\beta_1, \beta_2, \beta_3). reflects fundamental difficulty estimating curvature masked data: shape determines hazard changes, scale determines sits. DFR shapes (k<1k < 1) hardest. Component 1 (k1=0.8k_1 = 0.8) tends show largest relative estimation error among shapes. k<1k < 1, hazard diverges t→0t \0, making likelihood surface sensitive shape parameter near boundary. Coverage near nominal. Wald confidence intervals achieve approximately 95% coverage across parameters, validating asymptotic normal approximation sample size. 2m-parameter model identifiable. Despite doubling parameters relative homogeneous model, six parameters consistently recovered. Identifiability relies candidate sets conveying information component caused failure; without (.e., p=1p = 1, maximum masking), model identifiable.

code: library(likelihood.model.series.md)  # --- Exponential model --- model <- exp_series_md_c1_c2_c3()  # Generate masked series data gen <- rdata(model) df <- gen(theta = c(1.0, 1.1, 0.95), n = 500, tau = 3, p = 0.3)  # Fit via MLE solver <- fit(model) mle <- solver(df, par = c(1, 1, 1)) mle$theta.hat   # estimated rates mle$sigma       # asymptotic standard errors  # Log-likelihood, score, and Hessian ll <- loglik(model) s  <- score(model) H  <- hess_loglik(model)  ll(df, par = mle$theta.hat) s(df, par = mle$theta.hat) H(df, par = mle$theta.hat)  # --- Weibull model (shared shape) --- wmodel <- wei_series_homogeneous_md_c1_c2_c3() wsolver <- fit(wmodel) # theta: (shape, scale1, scale2, ...) # wmle <- wsolver(data, par = c(1.2, 1000, 900, 850))

text: reduced model components share common shape parameter k, retaining individual scale parameters. parameter vector (k, scale_1, ..., scale_m), giving m+1 parameters instead 2m. key property model series system lifetime Weibull distributed shape k scale lambda_s = (sum(scale_j^-k))^-1/k. model satisfies concept likelihood_model likelihood.model package providing following methods: (1) loglik.wei_series_homogeneous_md_c1_c2_c3 (2) score.wei_series_homogeneous_md_c1_c2_c3 (3) hess_loglik.wei_series_homogeneous_md_c1_c2_c3 likelihood model, masked component data approximately satisfies: C1: Pr{K[] C[]} = 1 C2: Pr{C[]=c[] | K[]=j, T[]=t[]} = Pr{C[]=c[] | K[]=j', T[]=t[]} j, j' c[]. C3: masking probabilities independent theta
